title: What is the concept of "bene" according to Plotinus and how does it relate to the absence of desire?
first_phrase: In this philosophical text, Plotinus discusses the concept of "the good" as the absence of anything that could take one's attention away from their true being. In this final part of the text, he emphasizes the spiritual nature of this concept and the importance of being self-sufficient. He also notes that only through detachment from all other ideas and concepts can one truly experience "the good". This state of being brings with it a sense of completeness and certainty, where there is no need for further searching or speculation. The text ends with the idea that one who possesses their own life fully possesses eternity, and that being present in the moment is the highest state of being.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the attainment of the ultimate good is only possible through a spiritual act that disconnects the self from worldly desires and reunites it with its own being. Once this state is achieved, there is no need for anything else, and a sense of certainty and fulfillment takes over. By being present and living in the moment, happiness can be found in this universe even amidst struggles. Let us strive to attain this true state of being and live a fulfilling life.
